docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Welcome to the comprehensive documentation for the API, which provides both REST and WebSocket endpoints for controlling and interacting Mirokai robots.

This documentation aims to help developers understand and use the API effectively, enabling integration with various applications and systems.

This documentation covers the various data types availables in the API, with associated endpoints, structured by the type of data they accept.

It also contains the detail of all functions available in this API.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This part of the documentation explains how to interact with the API using tokens, API keys, and client IDs. The API requires authentication through an API key, which generates a JWT token containing the client ID and its access level. This token must be used in subsequent requests for secure access.

docs.title: Authentication Flow
docs.text:
1. API Key Validation: Clients must include their API key in the request headers.
  2. JWT Token Generation: The server generates a JWT token upon successful API key validation.
  3. Token Usage: The JWT token must be included in the Authorization header for subsequent requests.

docs.title: API Key
docs.text: Each client is provided with a unique API key. This key must be included in the X-API-Key header for authentication.

docs.title: Client ID
docs.text: The Client ID is associated with the API key and included in the JWT token. This ID is used to identify and authorize specific actions.

docs.title: Request
docs.text:
URL: /api/v1/auth/

Method: GET

Headers: - X-API-Key: Your unique API key

API Response:

{ client_id: "your_client_ID", access_level: "your_access_level" }

docs.title: Example using requests in Python
docs.text:
import requests

# Define the URL and the endpoint
url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/auth/"

# Define the headers with the API key
headers = {
    "X-API-Key": "your_api_key_here"
}

# Make the GET request
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)

# Print the response
print(response.json())

# Get the JWT token from the response headers
jwt_token = response.headers.get("Authorization").split()[1]
print(f"JWT Token: {jwt_token}")

docs.title: Example using curl
docs.text: curl -X GET "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/auth/" -H "X-API-Key: your_api_key_here"

docs.title: Using the JWT Token for Subsequent Requests
docs.text: After obtaining the JWT token, include it in the Authorization header for all subsequent requests.

docs.title: Example using POST method and requests in Python
docs.text:
import requests
import jwt

# Define the URL and the endpoint
url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/coordinates/"

# Define the headers with the JWT token
headers = {
    "Authorization": f"Bearer {jwt_token}"
}

# Define the payload/data to send with the request
data = {"command": "go_to_relative", "value": {"x": 1.5, "y": -0.5, "z": 0.0, "theta": 3.14}}

# Make the POST request
response = requests.post(url, json=data, headers=headers)

# Print the response
print(response.json())

docs.title: Example using POST method with curl
docs.text:
curl -X POST "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/coordinates/" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer <JWT_TOKEN>" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{"command": "go_to_relative", "value": {"x": 1.5, "y": -0.5, "z": 0.0, "theta": 3.14}}'

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Keep Your API Key Secure: Never share your API key publicly. Treat it as sensitive information.
  2. Use HTTPS: Always use HTTPS to encrypt your API requests and responses.
  3. Token Expiration: The JWT token includes an expiration time (30mn). Make sure to handle token expiration in your client application by requesting a new token when needed.
  4. Token Storage: Store the JWT token securely in your client application. Avoid storing it in locations that are easily accessible, such as local storage or cookies.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: This documentation provides the necessary steps to authenticate and interact with the API securely. By following these guidelines and using the provided examples, clients can ensure secure and authenticated communication with the API.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
To start using the API, you need to obtain an API key (TO BE IMPLEMENTED) and authenticate your requests. The API supports both RESTful and WebSocket protocols for different types of interactions.

  • REST API: Ideal for standard, stateless operations where each request is independent.
  • WebSocket API: Suitable for real-time, continuous data streaming and interaction.

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text: • Version 1.0: Initial release with basic REST and WebSocket functionalities.

docs.title: Common Errors
docs.text: List of common errors for both REST and WebSocket APIs.

docs.title: Error 400: Bad Request
docs.text:
• Description: The request was invalid or cannot be otherwise served.
  • Example Response: 
    {
  "status": "error",
  "message": "Invalid request format."
}

docs.title: Error 401: Unauthorized
docs.text:
• Description: Authentication failed or user does not have permissions.
  • Example Response: ```json

{ "status": "error", "message": "Unauthorized access." } ```

docs.title: Error 404: Not Found
docs.text:
• Description: The requested resource could not be found.
  • Example Response: 
    {
  "status": "error",
  "message": "Resource not found."
}

docs.title: Error 500: Internal Server Error
docs.text:
• Description: An error occurred on the server.
  • Example Response: 
    {
  "status": "error",
  "message": "Internal server error."
}

docs.title: Q: What is the difference between the REST API and the WebSocket API?
docs.text:
• A: The REST API is designed for stateless operations where each request from the client to the server must contain all the information the server needs to fulfill that request. It's suitable for operations that don't require real-time updates.

The WebSocket API, on the other hand, provides a persistent connection allowing for full-duplex communication, making it ideal for real-time data streaming and interactive applications.

docs.title: Q: How do I obtain my API key?
docs.text: • A: API keys are usually provided during the registration process. If you haven't received your API key, please contact our support team at support@example.com.

docs.title: Q: What should I do if my API key is not working?
docs.text: • A: Ensure that the API key is correctly included in the Authorization header of your requests. If the issue persists, contact support to verify your API key and permissions.

docs.title: Q: How do I authenticate requests to the REST API?
docs.text:
• A: Include your API key in the Authorization header as follows: 
    Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY

docs.title: Q: What content types does the REST API accept?
docs.text: • A: The REST API accepts JSON-formatted data. Ensure your Content-Type header is set to application/json for all requests that include a body.

docs.title: Q: How can I test the REST API?
docs.text: • A: You can use tools like curl, Postman, or any HTTP client library in your preferred programming language to test the REST API.

docs.title: Q: Can I batch multiple requests into one?
docs.text: • A: Currently, the API does not support batching multiple requests into a single call. Each request must be made individually.

docs.title: Q: How do I authenticate my WebSocket connection?
docs.text:
• A: Include your API key in the initial connection request or as a message after establishing the connection. For example: 
    {
  "type": "authenticate",
  "api_key": "YOUR_API_KEY"
}

docs.title: Q: How do I subscribe to specific events or channels?
docs.text:
• A: Send a subscription message in JSON format to the WebSocket server. For example: 
    {
  "subscribe": "telemetry"
}

docs.title: Q: How can I handle reconnections if the WebSocket connection drops?
docs.text: • A: Implement a reconnection strategy in your client application to automatically attempt to reconnect when the connection is lost. Use exponential backoff or a fixed retry interval to manage reconnection attempts.

docs.title: Q: How do I close the WebSocket connection properly?
docs.text:
• A: Send a close frame to the server and then close the connection from the client side. For example: 
    await websocket.close()

docs.title: Q: What message formats are used in the WebSocket API?
docs.text: • A: All messages are in JSON format. Ensure that both the requests you send and the responses you receive are properly formatted JSON objects.

docs.title: Q: How do I debug WebSocket connection issues?
docs.text: • A: Use WebSocket debugging tools such as browser developer tools or dedicated WebSocket clients to inspect the messages and connection status. Check for correct URL, proper authentication, and valid message formats.

docs.title: Q: How can I handle errors in the WebSocket API?
docs.text: • A: Listen for error events and handle them appropriately in your client code. Ensure that you implement proper error handling for message parsing errors, connection errors, and subscription errors.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text:
• API: Application Programming Interface
  • JSON: JavaScript Object Notation
  • REST: Representational State Transfer
  • WebSocket: A protocol for full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Common issues and solutions.

  • Issue: Invalid JSON format

  • Solution: Ensure your request body is well-formed JSON.

  • Issue: Authentication failed

  • Solution: Check your API key and ensure it is included in the headers.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The REST API provides endpoints to perform various operations on the robot, such as moving, adjusting settings, and retrieving information.

Base URL: http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
TO UPDATE

All REST API requests require an API key included in the request headers.

docs.title: API Data Types Documentation
docs.text: This section details the specific data types utilized by the API.

docs.title: 1. Coordinates
docs.text:
• Data Type Description: Used to specify relative movement or positioning in a 3D space.
  • Structure: A JSON object containing four keys:
  • x (float): The X-coordinate (forward/backward).
  • y (float): The Y-coordinate (left/right).
  • z (float): The Z-coordinate (upward/downward). Z will always be equal to 0 for navigation.
  • theta (float): The angular rotation in radians.
  • velocity (float): The velocity to use with command. Default is 0.5.
  • Example Value: 
    {"x": 1.5, "y": -0.5, "z": 0.0, "theta": 3.14, "velocity": 0.5}

docs.title: 2. Float
docs.text:
• Data Type Description: A floating-point number typically used for precision measurements such as settings or levels.
  • Structure: A single floating-point value.
  • Example Value: 
    0.8

docs.title: 3. String
docs.text:
• Data Type Description: A sequence of characters used to represent textual data.
  • Structure: A single string value.
  • Example Value: 
    "wave"

docs.title: 4. Boolean
docs.text:
• Data Type Description: A true or false value, used for toggling states or binary settings.
  • Structure: A true or false value, represented as a Boolean in JSON.
  • Example Value: 
    true

docs.title: 5. Dictionary
docs.text:
• Data Type Description: A collection of key-value pairs, where each key is a unique identifier and the value is the data associated with that key.
  • Structure: A JSON object containing keys and values, which can be of various types.
  • Example Value: 
    {"name": "reac_intensity", "value": 0.8}

Each of these data types is integral to the operation of the API, allowing users to specify detailed parameters for various commands. When interacting with the API, it's essential to ensure that the data sent in requests matches these expected formats to ensure correct operation and avoid errors.

docs.title: Endpoints by Data Type
docs.text: Each endpoint has an associated functionality described, along with example shell and Python commands to interact with the API.

docs.title: 1. Coordinates
docs.text:
• Endpoint: /api/v1/coordinates/
  • Method:: POST
  • Shell Command: 
    curl -X POST "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/coordinates/" \
   -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   -d '{"command": "<command>", "value": {"x": 1.5, "y": -0.5, "z": 0.0, "theta": 3.14}}'
  • Python Command: 
    import requests

url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/coordinates/"
data = {
    "command": "<command>",
    "value": {"x": 1.5, "y": -0.5, "z": 0.0, "theta": 3.14}
}
response = requests.post(url, json=data)
print(response.text)
  • Note: NO COMMAND IS USING THIS ENDPOINT

docs.title: 2. Float
docs.text:
• Endpoint: /api/v1/float/
  • Function example: Sets the maximum velocity at which the robot can operate in percentage
  • Method:: POST
  • Shell Command: 
    curl -X POST "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/int/" \
   -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   -d '{"command": "set_robot_max_velocity", "value": 50}'
  • Python Command: 
    import requests

url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/int/"
data = {
    "command": "set_robot_max_velocity",
    "value": 50
}
response = requests.post(url, json=data)
print(response.text)

docs.text:
• Endpoint: /api/v1/int/

data = {

response = requests.post(url, json=data)

docs.title: 4. String
docs.text:
• Endpoint: /api/v1/str/
  • Function example: Checks if a rune has been detected.
  • Method:: POST
  • Shell Command: 
    curl -X POST "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/str/" \
   -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   -d '{"command": "is_detected", "value": "rune_id"}'
  • Python Command: 
    import requests

url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/str/"
data = {
    "command": "is_detected",
    "value": "rune_id"
}
response = requests.post(url, json=data)
print(response.text)

docs.title: 5. Boolean
docs.text:
• Endpoint: /api/v1/bool/
  • Function example: Toggles the obstacle avoidance feature.
  • Method:: POST
  • Shell Command: 
    curl -X POST "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/bool/" \
   -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   -d '{"command": "set_obstacle_avoidance", "value": "true"}'
  • Python Command: 
    import requests

url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/bool/"
data = {
    "command": "set_obstacle_avoidance",
    "value": True  # Use Python's boolean True instead of the string "true"
}
response = requests.post(url, json=data)
print(response.text)

docs.title: 6. Dictionary
docs.text:
• Endpoint: /api/v1/dict/
  • Function example: Trigger a wave animation.
  • Method:: POST
  • Shell Command: 
    curl -X POST "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/dict/" \
   -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   -d '{"command": "skill", "value": {name: wave}}'
  • Python Command: 
    import requests

url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/dict/"
data = {
    "command": "skill",
    "value": {"name": "wave"}}
}
response = requests.post(url, json=data)
print(response.text)

docs.title: 7. Get / Commands with no argument
docs.text:
This endpoint is to send either a command with no argument, either to get data. - Endpoint: /api/v1/get/{command}/ - Function example: Get robot's language. - Method:: GET - Shell Command: 

curl -L "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/get/get_language/"
- Python Command: 
import requests

url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/get/get_language/"
response = requests.get(url)
print(response.text)

docs.title: 8. Get available services list
docs.text:
This endpoint is to get available services list.

  • Endpoint: /api/v1/service/get_services_list/
  • Function example: Get robot's services list for head and base
  • Method:: GET
  • Shell Command: 
    curl -L "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/service/get_services_list/"
  • Python Command: 
    import requests

url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/service/get_services_list/"
response = requests.get(url)
print(response.text)

docs.title: 9. Get services logs
docs.text:
This endpoint is to get last hour services logs from user services of a specific system (head or base).

  • Endpoint: /api/v1/service/{system_name}/{service_name}
  • Function example: Get logs of enchanted_stack.service for the base.
  • Method:: GET
  • Shell Command: 
    curl -L "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/service/base/enchanted_stack.service/"
  • Python Command: 
    import requests

url = "http://<ROBOT_IP>:8000/api/v1/service/base/enchanted_stack.service/"
response = requests.get(url)
print(response.text)

Each endpoint except NoArgCommand supports a POST method where JSON data can be sent as part of the request to interact with different functionalities provided by the API.

docs.title: API Functions Documentation
docs.text: This documentation provides comprehensive details about each function accessible through the API. It includes the purpose of each function, the specific endpoint to use, the type of data each function accepts, and example JSON inputs.

## Associate a rune

  • Description: Associate a rune with its properties, based on the rune ID.
  • Endpoint: /api/v1/dict/
  • Type of Argument: Dict
  • JSON Example: 
    {"command": "rune_association",
 "value": {

      "label": "Rune to trigger wave",
      "class": "rune_wave",
}
  • Available rune types:
    • "rune_speaker"
    • "rune_handle"
    • "rune_call"
    • "rune_kiss"
    • "rune_sleeping"
    • "rune_wave"
    • "rune_mute"

docs.title: Data Streamed by the Robot:
docs.text: The robot streams the following data:

docs.title: grasping_state
docs.text:
• Description: Current grasping state.
  • Type of Argument: enchanted.vokarina.pyvokarina.GraspState
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: battery_voltage
docs.text:
• Description: Battery voltage.
  • Type of Argument: Float
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: current_focus
docs.text:
• Description: Vision's focus priority.
  • Type of Argument: String
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: head_mode
docs.text:
• Description: Current neck mode.
  • Type of Argument: enchanted.vokarina.pyvokarina.NeckMode
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: navigation_state
docs.text:
• Description: Current navigation state.
  • Type of Argument: enchanted.vokarina.pyvokarina.NavigationState
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: left_hand_state
docs.text:
• Description: Left hand state (open, closed).
  • Type of Argument: enchanted.vokarina.pyvokarina.HandStatus
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: right_hand_state
docs.text:
• Description: Right hand state (open, closed).
  • Type of Argument: enchanted.vokarina.pyvokarina.HandStatus
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: tofs_faulty_state
docs.text:
• Description: State of Time-of-Flight sensors indicating if any are faulty.
  • Type of Argument: Bool
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: is_balancing
docs.text:
• Description: True if the robot has balancing enabled.
  • Type of Argument: Bool
  • Frequency: 1Hz

docs.title: runes
docs.text:
• Description: All detected runes indexed by hardware ID, their virtual ID, whether they are clicked, double-clicked, or long-pressed, their label, type, angle of arrival, and RSSI.
  • Type of Argument: Dict
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: max_velocity
docs.text:
• Description: Current maximum velocity.
  • Type of Argument: Float
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: grasp_auto_choice
docs.text:
• Description: True if the robot chooses the arm to grasp autonomously; False otherwise.
  • Type of Argument: Bool
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: grasp_side
docs.text:
• Description: The arm set to grasp, represented as {name: "ARM_RIGHT", value: 1} or {name: "ARM_LEFT", value: 0}.
  • Type of Argument: Dict
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: arms_collision
docs.text:
• Description: Indicates whether the robot's arms are in a collision state.
  • Type of Argument: Bool
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: semantic_memory
docs.text:
• Description: Information from the robot's semantic memory.
  • Type of Argument: List
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: llm_enabled
docs.text:
• Description: True if the robot is using a Language Learning Model (LLM); False otherwise.
  • Type of Argument: Bool
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: is_voice_trigger_activated
docs.text:
• Description: Indicates whether voice trigger for movement activation is enabled.
  • Type of Argument: Bool
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: runes_by_id
docs.text:
• Description: All detected runes indexed by virtual ID, their hardware ID, whether they are clicked, double-clicked, or long-pressed, their label, type, angle of arrival, and RSSI.
  • Type of Argument: Dict
  • Frequency: 5Hz

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Here's the updated documentation for the server side to include information about using JWT tokens for authentication with WebSockets:

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The WebSocket API provides real-time, continuous data streaming from the robot to the client. This is ideal for applications that require up-to-the-second updates, such as telemetry and live monitoring.

WebSocket URL: ws://<ROBOT_IP>:8001

docs.title: Connecting to the WebSocket
docs.text: To connect to the WebSocket, use the WebSocket URL and include the JWT token in the initial request as a query parameter.

docs.title: Example using websockets in Python
docs.text:
import asyncio
import websockets

async def connect_to_websocket():
    jwt_token = "your_jwt_token_here"
    ws_url = f"ws://<ROBOT_IP>:8001?token={jwt_token}"
    async with websockets.connect(ws_url) as websocket:
        print("Connected to WebSocket")
        # Subscribe to a topic
        await websocket.send(json.dumps({"action": "subscribe", "topic": "server_logs"}))
        # Receive messages
        async for message in websocket:
            print(f"Received message: {message}")

asyncio.run(connect_to_websocket())

docs.title: Example using JavaScript
docs.text:
const token = "your_jwt_token_here";
const ws = new WebSocket(`ws://<ROBOT_IP>:8001?token=${token}`);

ws.onopen = function(event) {
    console.log("WebSocket connection established");
    // Subscribe to a topic
    ws.send(JSON.stringify({ action: "subscribe", topic: "server_logs" }));
};

ws.onmessage = function(event) {
    console.log("Message from server", event.data);
};

ws.onerror = function(error) {
    console.log("WebSocket error", error);
};

ws.onclose = function(event) {
    console.log("WebSocket connection closed", event);
};

docs.title: Messages
docs.text:
To subscribe to a topic:

{
  "action": "subscribe",
  "topic": "some_topic"
}

To unsubscribe from a topic:

{
  "action": "unsubscribe",
  "topic": "some_topic"
}

To publish data to a topic:

{
  "action": "publish",
  "topic": "some_topic",
  "data": {"name": "name_of_data", "type": "type_of_data", "data": "your_data_here"}
}

docs.title: System logs
docs.text: Some system logs are published by the WebSocket server on the "server_logs" topic. Subscribe to this topic to get the server messages.

docs.title: Python examples:
docs.text: Here you will find some python examples to display data streamed with websocket. Both asynchronous and synchronous examples are provided.

docs.title: Asynchronous
docs.text:
The following script is showing how to use websockets with python.

Subscription: The scripts subscribe to grasping_state, navigation_state, and battery_voltage topics after establishing the WebSocket connection.

*Publishing Data: The scripts demonstrate publishing data to a topic named some_topic.

Unsubscription: The scripts unsubscribe from the previously subscribed topics.

import asyncio
import websockets
import json
from typing import Dict, Any

async def listen() -> None:
    """
    Connect to the WebSocket server and continuously listen for messages.
    Prints the name, type, and data from each received message.
    """
    uri: str = "ws://<ROBOT_IP>:8001"
    async with websockets.connect(uri) as websocket:
        # Subscribe to topics
        await websocket.send(json.dumps({"action": "subscribe", "topic": "grasping_state"}))
        await websocket.send(json.dumps({"action": "subscribe", "topic": "navigation_state"}))
        await websocket.send(json.dumps({"action": "subscribe", "topic": "battery_voltage"}))

        # Example of publishing data to a topic
        await websocket.send(json.dumps({
            "action": "publish",
            "topic": "some_topic",
            "data": {"example_key": "example_value"}
        }))

        try:
            await asyncio.wait_for(receive_messages(websocket), timeout=5.0)
        except asyncio.TimeoutError:
            print("Finished listening for 5 seconds.")

        # Unsubscribe from topics
        await websocket.send(json.dumps({"action": "unsubscribe", "topic": "grasping_state"}))
        await websocket.send(json.dumps({"action": "unsubscribe", "topic": "navigation_state"}))
        await websocket.send(json.dumps({"action": "unsubscribe", "topic": "battery_voltage"}))

async def receive_messages(websocket) -> None:
    async for message in websocket:
        data: Dict[str, Any] = json.loads(message)
        print(f"[Name]: {data['name']}\n[Type]: {data['type']}\n[Data]: {data['data']}\n")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(listen())

docs.title: Synchronous
docs.text:
The following script is showing how to use websockets with python.

Subscription: The scripts subscribe to grasping_state, navigation_state, and battery_voltage topics after establishing the WebSocket connection.

*Publishing Data: The scripts demonstrate publishing data to a topic named some_topic.

Unsubscription: The scripts unsubscribe from the previously subscribed topics.

Note: You will first need to install websocket-client library with the command: 

pip install websocket-client


import json
import websocket
import threading
import time
from typing import Dict, Any

def on_message(ws: websocket.WebSocketApp, message: str) -> None:
    """
    Callback function that processes received messages.

    Args:
        ws (websocket.WebSocketApp): The WebSocketApp instance.
        message (str): The received message as a JSON string.
    """
    data: Dict[str, Any] = json.loads(message)
    print(f"[Name]: {data['name']}\n[Type]: {data['type']}\n[Data]: {data['data']}\n")

def on_error(ws: websocket.WebSocketApp, error: str) -> None:
    """
    Callback function that handles errors.

    Args:
        ws (websocket.WebSocketApp): The WebSocketApp instance.
        error (str): The error message.
    """
    print(f"Error: {error}")

def on_close(ws: websocket.WebSocketApp, close_status_code: int, close_msg: str) -> None:
    """
    Callback function that handles the WebSocket closing.

    Args:
        ws (websocket.WebSocketApp): The WebSocketApp instance.
        close_status_code (int): The status code for the WebSocket closing.
        close_msg (str): The closing message.
    """
    print("Connection closed")

def on_open(ws: websocket.WebSocketApp) -> None:
    """
    Callback function that handles the WebSocket opening.

    Args:
        ws (websocket.WebSocketApp): The WebSocketApp instance.
    """
    print("Connection opened")

    # Subscribe to topics
    ws.send(json.dumps({"action": "subscribe", "topic": "grasping_state"}))
    ws.send(json.dumps({"action": "subscribe", "topic": "navigation_state"}))
    ws.send(json.dumps({"action": "subscribe", "topic": "battery_voltage"}))

    # Example of publishing data to a topic
    ws.send(json.dumps({
        "action": "publish",
        "topic": "some_topic",
        "data": {"example_key": "example_value"}
    }))

def run_websocket(ws: websocket.WebSocketApp) -> None:
    """
    Run the WebSocket and listen for messages for 5 seconds.

    Args:
        ws (websocket.WebSocketApp): The WebSocketApp instance.
    """
    ws.run_forever()

def stop_websocket(ws: websocket.WebSocketApp) -> None:
    """
    Close the WebSocket connection and unsubscribe from topics after 5 seconds.

    Args:
        ws (websocket.WebSocketApp): The WebSocketApp instance.
    """
    time.sleep(5)
    ws.send(json.dumps({"action": "unsubscribe", "topic": "grasping_state"}))
    ws.send(json.dumps({"action": "unsubscribe", "topic": "navigation_state"}))
    ws.send(json.dumps({"action": "unsubscribe", "topic": "battery_voltage"}))
    ws.close()
    print("Finished listening for 5 seconds and unsubscribed from topics.")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    uri: str = "ws://<ROBOT_IP>:8001"
    ws: websocket.WebSocketApp = websocket.WebSocketApp(
        uri,
        on_message=on_message,
        on_error=on_error,
        on_close=on_close)
    ws.on_open = on_open

    # Run the WebSocket in a separate thread
    websocket_thread = threading.Thread(target=run_websocket, args=(ws,))
    websocket_thread.start()

    # Stop the WebSocket after 5 seconds
    stop_thread = threading.Thread(target=stop_websocket, args=(ws,))
    stop_thread.start()

    websocket_thread.join()
    stop_thread.join()
